So we’re not talking about window-dressing here. Imposing monetary penalties for union-busting would be monumental—the first change to the National Labor Relations Act making it easier for workers to form unions since 1935. And the American people are on our side.

And this isn’t a side issue: @EconomicPolicy found that employers are charged with violating the law in 41.5 percent of union organizing drives. If those law-breakers had to pay penalties, that would bring in real revenue.

Under our current labor laws, the federal government can’t impose monetary penalties even when corporations break the law in the most flagrant ways you can imagine—even if they fire workers for trying to form a union. Union-busting gets a slap on the wrist, if that.

Right now, most of the #PROAct would be subject to the Senate filibuster (unless/until we abolish that Jim Crow relic). But not the entire bill! Monetary penalties for union-busting could pass with a simple majority. And they are popular: https://www.dataforprogress.org/blog/2021/7/29/rep-andy-levin-pro-act
